body: happy to address any feedback post-merge!
Note: this is now running in production at Twitter
:+1: let's see what breaks next
:broken_heart:
lol!
Thanks!

### @abesto brings you:

# The Zipkin Release Process!

[![IMAGE ALT TEXT](http://img.youtube.com/vi/AuUVBprLGKU/0.jpg)](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuUVBprLGKU"Zipkin release process")

Great work! I haven't been involved in any releasing (yet), the graph was very informative!
Another graph will be upcoming with new release process.
+cc @rtyler @jamescway @adriancole
I like this flow, it is well documented and covers the cases, we've got so far.

per chat in gitter, disabling the daemon during CI is acceptable. We're leaving the config in gradle.properties to help ease developer setup. IOTW, we can adjust the mem args needed without needing to notify all developers to update `~/.gradle/gradle.properties`
Thanks for chipping the way towards snapshots.

Can you separate the bug fix from the enhancement?

The enhancement will be confusing to those who don't set this variable, which will be everyone except you. I'd personally prefer no environment in the UI than a false one.
Sure. Doing that now.
gracias!

cc @adriancole @eirslett
I will post a screenshot in the zipkin chat room
LGTM! +1
Change looks good! I'd love to have a follow-up that drops the internal constants that just snake case things, but it isn't blocking.
I can't wait to use this!
Nice! :+1:

Sad we need to check in a big text file to accomplish this :(

:shipit: on green
is there a way to re-run travis builds?

Yep. You should have a login with github option at the top when you click
into Travis link. Once logged into travis, there should be a circular arrow
you can click to kick a job.
well that was obvious :-)
Whoah.. Is this for real?! :)
Real, absolutely. We don't yet know if it'll work, but it's most definitely real!

Another observation - before the upgrade the Zipkin code had a -D switch to control the number of buckets, such that setting that param to 1 bucket would've been equivalent to the current/new schema. If we extend the schema as suggested above, people will have an option to use or not use the bucketing, with little overhead if they don't want to use it.

Indeed there will be hot spots on the `service_name` in this table.
That there was bucketing happening before I definitely missed.
bucketCount and "zipkin.store.cassie.indexBuckets", as you mention defaulted to ten previously.

it's pretty much in all tables, e.g. annotations_index for standard annotations like cs/cr/ss/sr will be always hitting row key `"${serviceName}:${annotation}"`. The old code was using BucketedColumnFamily for most of the tables.
yes. thanks for spotting this. i'll have a fix out in the next hour or so.

also, if we go for a dedicated bucket column included in the composite row key, I would suggest changing the schema for annotations_index. Right now it is stored as a composite string `${serviceName}:${annotation} [:$annotationValue]`. I would suggest the following schema instead:

```
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS zipkin.annotations_index (
    service_name      string,
    annotation_name   string,
    annotation_value  blob, -- optional for non-binary annotations.
    bucket_no      tinyint,
    ts             timestamp,
    trace_id       bigint,
    PRIMARY KEY ((service_name, annotation_name, annotation_value, bucket_no), ts)
)
```

that would be a separate ticket @yurishkuro 
i looked into that while doing the related pull request, but because there's a blob there i left it for now. in a later pull request i'd like to remove all the blobs so we have a completely transparent schema.
Now that the big switch to use datastax is is committed, we can revisit this issue... :grin:
at least keeping the bucket number as a separate column would be useful to start with.
Should we close this ticket?

This can be done with the Repository.java class now.

Schema creation is automatic and tested.

I'm thinking with migration it's just about versioning the keyspace name and creating a new keyspace whenever there's an incompatible change.

Simple migrations for compatible changes can also be achieved (eg "ALTER TABLE...")
@yurishkuro you want to take a look at that pull request for us?
Looks good, just missing the schema change for `service_name` table.

i really don't think bucketing will help for service_name.

and while we get hot partitions there, beyond "tombstones" (old writes), each partition only ever has one column. it might be smarter to change the compaction to LeveledCompactionStrategy rather than bucketing. i also added a comment in the code regarding caching writes, since this table is going to see basically just duplicated writes going to it.

work is started in https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/cb9f063f5e9b

it's implemented i believe but just needs a unit test for it.

I agree, bucketing doesn't seem particularly helpful for service names. But the pull request does contain code to use buckets for this table, so I was pointing out to mismatch with the schema. Maybe undo the code change for this table?

noooooo, where? :-) 

(might be easier to write those comments against the code lines in the PR)

I realize that I didn't call it out in the original issue description, so maybe it should be addressed in a follow-on, but I believe the support for providing credentials should support the possibility of **securely** providing the credentials.

Different organizations will certainly have different mechanisms for providing these credentials, so perhaps the implementation should provide an interface for providing credentials. The default implementation may be as simple as the command line option approach used here (and/or securely prompting for credentials).
sorry. my bad, got tripped by the column name. Good to go!

Yeah, i just wanted to throw a simple implementation out there to begin with.

You also have the AuthProvider class in the datastax cql driver, along with the PlainTextAuthProvider implementation of it.

Two notes, neither one blocking. Other than those, LGTM :+1: 

Very excited, once this is merged, we might have a release on Maven Central :)

In jclouds we had stores that acted differently wrt consistency. We created
a method "assertEventually" that invoked an assertion with exponential
backoff (ex invoked both the retrieve and compare) where this was permitted
to be different.

Where it wasn't permitted to be different, the stores themselves blocked
before they returned success. This allowed all stores to have the same
behavior regardless of impl. Otherwise, as @abesto said, people will be
very surprised to find they can't read their writes.

I'd suggest changing this code to subclass CassandraSpanStore upon
initialization. Override setttl with a method that calls super then has the
blocking loop before returning. This allows the test to stay in tact (ex
not subject to copy/paste drift).

Add to the README that this op is eventually consistent.

Wdyt?

> Otherwise, as @abesto said, people will be
> very surprised to find they can't read their writes.

How would people know?
Arn't the writes we're talking about here coming from an event system, and the system at large is already asynchronous?
I think trying to make the store strictly consistent is a bit of a pointless exercise here.

> I'd suggest changing this code to subclass CassandraSpanStore upon
> initialization. Override setttl with a method that calls super then has the
> blocking loop before returning. This allows the test to stay in tact (ex
> not subject to copy/paste drift).

My scala remains too young to accomplish that.
Could you provide an example?

>  people will be very surprised to find they can't read their writes.

maybe you mean by "people" the zipkin developers rather the zipkin users?
if so, is there any reason to not presume that all stores are eventually consistent, since that would be a) the design of the system we're working with at large, and b) beneficial to performance as it will prevent read-before-write anti-patterns creeping into the code.

i don't know… it's a more involved discussion than that in regards to the user.
and yes it would have been nice if the Repository.storeSpan(..) returned a java future that was wrapped into a scala/twitter future.

> How would people know?
> Arn't the writes we're talking about here coming from an event system,
> and the system at large is already asynchronous?
> A developer of SpanStore should know what expectations are, especially as
> this is the only time we've hit this.

Maybe just document the method as 'Returns once the backend accepts the ttl
request'. Or document the whole SpanStore type as 'all commands that return
void are processed asynchronously'

> I think trying to make the store strictly consistent is a bit of a
> pointless exercise here.
> Not about that, just saying it is now (else all stores would flake). We
> should document that it isn't.
> 
> My scala remains too young to accomplish that.
> Could you provide an example?
> Will do, but sadly need an hour to be at a laptop :(
PS I volunteer to address all of this post merge!
He said merge. Did you see him say merge? :)

He clicked merge.. Did you see him click merge? :)

I will fix the root issue later, which is that the SpanStore api needs to be documented and tested assuming writes are async.

the `service_span_name_index` table doesn't need buckets i believe (and didn't previously).

the combination of service and span is enough to avoid hot partitions.

you are right about splitting service and span columns. i will tackle that in a subsequent PR.
weird.. thought I merged this!

@michaelsembwever when do you plan to merge this? 

I've tested with my collector (written in Go), the new schema works well.
it's merged

These overrides feel like they'd be better as configurations options inside the release plugin. I may (or may not) get around to creating a PR for that to the plugin itself. As it is, we are on the border of abusing internals of the plugin instead of using the stable API.

:shipit:

completely on board with not running tests as a part of release process.
LGTM with nits
LGTM :)

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-cassandra/src/test/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/cassandra/CassandraSpanStoreFactorySpec.scala
ps in the future, you can just open a PR when you are proposing both the problem and the fix.

great job. Can you squash these into a single commit? I'll merge on green after.

> We don't need the fat jar for -aggregate

Do you mean we don't need the tar.gz file? Hadoop only accepts single jars, so one needs to ship it all-in-one.
That's right, thanks. Updated the description.

Wow. Much simpler! :shipit:

Does this still build the zip or tarball that isnt published? If so, eventually would be nice to not spend time making them. If no, fantastic!
Short answer: yes I think, we still build all the zips and tarballs (though I'm not 100% confident, we'll need to see). Added some context to the description.

a) not constrain endpoint except to be appropriately unique
b) make endpoint self-describing--just supporting ipv6 just kicks the can down the road, and not that far, for me
